page.title: 06GEOLOGY OF FROXFIELD AREA
page.content: The geolgy of the area can be divided into two categories. To the south-east there is heavy clay, which is divided from the rest of the area by two scarps which in turn are divided by 'Upper Green sand'. The rest is predominantly covered by chalk. It is thought that at one time a river may have run along the valley in which the main A272 now runs. Flint is also found in the area, but not on the two scarps. The main reason for the small number of settlements in the area is that the land was not good for farming, and so most of the early Saxon villages were on the 'Upper Green sand', but now farmers are persuaded by the EEC to farm land they would otherwise not. However,on the plateau,anything can be farmed as the soil is extremely rich in silica.
